Two attorneys from the Institute for Justice approached me back in 2002, and suggested that the time might be right for a Second Amendment challenge.

I added some legal expertise and a few dollars to the effort, and we went forward and signed up six plaintiffs and another attorney, and pressed forward with the suit, which took five and a half years to litigate.
My interest was plainly to vindicate the meaning of the Second Amendment and the right secured by the Second Amendment.
And in that effort we have succeeded, I'm happy to say.
The Second Amendment says, in part, a well-regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed.
But, you know, America during the revolution is not America today.

Have you ever thought that what you were litigating for is not what the founders intended?
Well, as you mentioned, Barack Obama has said the Second Amendment is not absolute.
I don't know anyone who believes that the Second Amendment is absolute.

After all, the First Amendment says Congress shall make no law about free speech, but we have rules against shouting fire in a crowded theater, an incitement to riot, an obscenity and defamation and extortion, and a whole line of cases that have upheld restrictions on free speech.

In the same sense, there are obviously some things that can be regulated, we did not deny that, you can keep weapons away from crazy people, from kids, you can keep weapons away from violent felons, you can keep some classes of weapons away from everybody, you can keep weapons out of highly sensitive areas, like elementary schools, for example.
So this is, I think, a straw man that the anti-gun folks have raised.
Responsible people, and I would count myself among them, do not argue for an absolutist view of the Second Amendment.
What do you think of studies, including a long-term study done in D.C.
and Baltimore that suggests that bans don't actually do anything to stop homicides and suicides tied to handguns?
Is this decision tied to that kind of a regulation?

There has been a great deal of literature on the effect of handgun bans and other gun regulations.
And I think it is quite clear to say that the weight of the data suggests that this hand gun bans have not been effective.
The most encompassing studies have been by two federal government agencies.

Back in 2004, the National Academy of Sciences reviewed 253 journal articles and 99 books and 43 government publications, and evaluated 80 gun control measures, and they couldn't identify a single gun control regulation - the reduced violent crime, or suicide, or accidents - and the Centers for Disease Control found the same thing.
So while there is evidence on both sides, I thing the weight of the evidence suggests that these gun laws do not work.
Washington, D.C.
is certainly a case in point.
But I want to emphasize that our law suit was about the meaning of the Constitution.
It was not solely about weighing scientific evidence and getting expert witnesses to testify about the effectiveness of gun laws.

If gun laws are effective, and I doubt that they are, but if they are, and yet the Second Amendment says we can have a gun for self-defense, if it is necessary to revise that, the answer is go repeal the Second Amendment.

It doesn't give carte blanche to anybody, in two respects.
First of all, the law suit is not about carrying guns outside the home.
This is about possessing an ordinary garden variety fire arm for self defense, within the home.
So with respect to going out on the streets of the nation's capital and shooting people, this law suit has nothing to say about that.
If that is going to be litigated, it will have to be litigated later.
The second issue is that the laws about self defense remain on the books.
You cannot, just because you have a right to a firearm in your home, willy-nilly shoot anybody that you feel like it within the context of your - the privacy of your own residence.
There are still laws that say when you can shoot in self defense and when you cannot.
Those laws have not been changed.

A group of hackers - allegedly from Russia - found a fundamental flaw in Microsoft Windows.
And they're believed to have exploited it to spy on Western governments, on NATO, on European energy companies and on an academic organization here in the U.S.
Now this is all according to new research from a cyber-security firm called iSight Partners.
NPR's Aarti Shahani has the story.
Last month, the U.S.
and the U.K.
were preparing to meet at a NATO summit - the North Atlantic Treaty Organization - to talk about Ukraine.
E-mails were flying back and forth.
Different experts were offering to talk at the conference.
And in the midst of all that digital traffic, hackers jumped into the conversation.
Patrick McBride, a spokesman with iSight, says they targeted specific officials.
So you would craft a message, it might have an attachment with a PowerPoint in it, say hey, you know, take a look at this PowerPoint, see if that makes sense.
We'd like to be involved in the conference, for example.
Or any number of other things that might get the attention.
A hacker group found a vulnerability in Microsoft software and launched a well-known kind of attack called spear phishing.
When an unknowing recipient opened the corrupted PowerPoint, the file was exploited.
To load a piece of malware onto the computer that the attacker can then use later.
